[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Cache bypass] Can an attacker craft state queries that deliberately miss the block cache to bypass caching layers, forcing expensive disk I/O that degrades consensus performance and causes validator slowdowns? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Index type confusion] Does convert_index_type() properly validate index_type (line 190), or can an attacker force incompatible index types that cause lookup failures, making critical state data inaccessible and halting transaction processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Filter partitioning attack] Can an attacker exploit partition_filters setting (line 191) to cause filter fragmentation, increasing false positive rates in bloom filters and degrading query performance to consensus-breaking levels? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [L0 pinning exhaustion] Does pin_l0_filter_and_index_blocks_in_cache (line 193-195) allow an attacker to force excessive L0 file creation, pinning unlimited data in cache and causing memory exhaustion on validator nodes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Bloom filter bypass] In the bloom filter configuration (line 201-206), can an attacker exploit the bits-per-key parameter to disable filtering entirely (e.g., bits = 0), causing full table scans that degrade performance and enable query-based DoS attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Hybrid ribbon vulnerability] Does the hybrid_ribbon_filter (line 203) with bloom_before_level threshold allow an attacker to force expensive ribbon filter operations on hot data, causing CPU exhaustion during state queries? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Whole key filtering attack] For STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME and HOT_STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME (line 208-212), disabling whole_key_filtering could allow prefix collision attacks where an attacker crafts keys with matching prefixes to cause incorrect state lookups? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Cache index consistency] Does cache_index_and_filter_blocks (line 192) create a consistency window where cached indexes become stale after compaction, allowing queries to return outdated state and causing double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: convert_index_type()] [Index type downgrade] Can an attacker exploit the simple match statement (lines 217-223) by forcing a downgrade from TwoLevelIndexSearch to BinarySearch, severely degrading lookup performance on large datasets and causing consensus timeouts? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: convert_index_type()] [Unvalidated conversion] Does this function validate that the requested index type is appropriate for the data size, or can an attacker force HashSearch on very large tables causing hash table overflow and incorrect lookups? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: with_state_key_extractor_processor()] [Extractor bypass] Can an attacker exploit the conditional application of prefix_extractor (lines 226-233) to cause some column families to use prefix extraction while others don't, leading to inconsistent state key lookups and data corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Buffer underflow] In line 237, the slice operation `&state_value_raw_key[..(state_value_raw_key.len() - VERSION_SIZE)]` can panic if state_value_raw_key.len() < VERSION_SIZE, allowing an attacker to crash validators by inserting malformed keys? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Version size manipulation] Is VERSION_SIZE (line 12) using std::mem::size_of::<Version>() guaranteed to match the actual serialized version size, or can serialization inconsistencies cause the extractor to return incorrect key prefixes, breaking state lookups? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Prefix collision] Can an attacker craft state keys where the prefix (key without version) collides with other keys, causing the prefix extractor to group unrelated state values together and return incorrect data during range queries? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_key_extractor()] [Version extraction attack] Can an attacker exploit the hardcoded VERSION_SIZE subtraction to craft keys where the 'version' portion contains malicious data that gets ignored by the extractor but processed by other systems, causing state inconsistencies? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_ledger_cfds()] [State key extractor mismatch] Does applying with_state_key_extractor_processor (line 312) to all ledger column families create vulnerabilities where non-state CFs like TRANSACTION_INFO_CF_NAME incorrectly use prefix extraction, causing transaction lookup failures?
